But it doesn't mean that it would be okay to adopt a seal today that would have a cross in it, does it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN

And what troubles me about this case is that, here, a citizen is going to a local community board, supposed to be the closest, the most responsive institution of government that exists, and is immediately being asked -- being forced to identify whether she believes in the things that most of the people in the room believe in, whether she belongs to the same religious team as most of the people in the room do. speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Justice Sotomayor.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Assuming -- you hear the resistance of some members of the Court to sitting as arbiters of what's sectarian and nonsectarian, and I join some skepticism as to knowing exactly where to join that line. Assuming you accept that, what would be the test that you would proffer, taking out your preferred announcement that this prayer has to be nonsectarian?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It just seems to me that enforcing that standard and the standard I suggested involves the State very heavily in the censorship and -- and the approval or disapproval of prayers.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That may play, ultimately, in your position if we say that that's why there shouldn't be any prayer at all.  But then you have the problem mentioned by Justice Scalia that we are misrepresenting who we really are.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's not a prayer. That's not a prayer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: "How many of you have been saved?"  That's not a prayer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Laycock, sort of, all hypotheticals aside, isn't the question mostly here, in most communities, whether the kind of language that I began with, which refers repeatedly to Jesus Christ, which is language that is accepted and admired and incredibly important to the majority members of a community, but is not accepted by a minority, whether that language will be allowed in a public town session like this one. That's really the question, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: That's the issue that actually arises.  Here's what -- I don't think that this is an easy question.  I think it's hard, because of this:  I think it's hard because the Court lays down these rules, and everybody thinks that the Court is Alderson Reporting Company being hostile to religion, and people get unhappy and angry and agitated in various kinds of ways.  This goes back to what Justice Breyer suggested. Part of what we are trying to do here is to maintain a multi-religious society in a peaceful and harmonious way.  And every time the Court gets involved in things like this, it seems to make the problem worse rather than better.  What do you think?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Suppose you did this:  You combined your two approaches.  The town has to -- it cannot -- it must make a good-faith effort to appeal to other religions who are in that area.  And then you have these words from the House, the chaplain should keep in Alderson Reporting Company mind that the House of Representatives -- or you would say whatever relevant group -- is comprised of members of many different faith traditions, period, end of matter. Is that sufficient, those two things?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Should we write that in a concurring opinion? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, I'm serious about this.  This -- this involves government very heavily in religion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, Marsh is not the source of the government involvement religion in this respect.  The first Congress is the source.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: The first Congress that also adopted the First Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Many of them -- many of them were very explicitly Christian, were they not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In a way, it sounds quite elitist to say, well, now, we can do this in Washington and Sacramento and Austin, Texas, but you people up there in Greece can't do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: My -- my understanding is that the first chaplain of the Senate was the Episcopal bishop of New York; isn't that correct?  And he used to read -- he took his prayers from the Book of Common Alderson Reporting Company Prayer.  That was acceptable to Baptists at the time, Quakers?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Laycock. Mr. Hungar, you have 3 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: One a year?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Four additional people after the suit was filed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: One a year?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How often does the legislature meet?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
